meeting_context:
# North Star & Strategic Context

This file combines the overall project mission (North Star) and summaries of key strategic documents for use in AI prompts, particularly for the AI Agent Council context generation.

**Last Updated:** December 2025

---

**North Star:**
To build the most reliable, developer-friendly open-source AI agent framework and cloud platform—enabling builders worldwide to deploy autonomous agents that work seamlessly across chains and platforms. We create infrastructure where agents and humans collaborate, forming the foundation for a decentralized AI economy that accelerates the path toward beneficial AGI.

---

**Core Principles:**
1. **Execution Excellence** - Reliability and seamless UX over feature quantity
2. **Developer First** - Great DX attracts builders; builders create ecosystem value
3. **Open & Composable** - Multi-agent systems that interoperate across platforms
4. **Trust Through Shipping** - Build community confidence through consistent delivery

---

**Current Product Focus (Dec 2025):**
- **ElizaOS Framework** (v1.6.x) - The core TypeScript toolkit for building persistent, interoperable agents
- **ElizaOS Cloud** - Managed deployment platform with integrated storage and cross-chain capabilities
- **Flagship Agents** - Reference implementations (Eli5, Otaku) demonstrating platform capabilities
- **Cross-Chain Infrastructure** - Native support for multi-chain agent operations via Jeju/x402

---

**ElizaOS Mission Summary:**
ElizaOS is an open-source "operating system for AI agents" aimed at decentralizing AI development. Built on three pillars: 1) The Eliza Framework (TypeScript toolkit for persistent agents), 2) AI-Enhanced Governance (building toward autonomous DAOs), and 3) Eliza Labs (R&D driving cloud, cross-chain, and multi-agent capabilities). The native token coordinates the ecosystem. The vision is an intelligent internet built on open protocols and collaboration.

---

**Taming Information Summary:**
Addresses the challenge of information scattered across platforms (Discord, GitHub, X). Uses AI agents as "bridges" to collect, wrangle (summarize/tag), and distribute information in various formats (JSON, MD, RSS, dashboards, council episodes). Treats documentation as a first-class citizen to empower AI assistants and streamline community operations.
monthly_goal: December 2025: Execution excellence—complete token migration with high success rate, launch ElizaOS Cloud, stabilize flagship agents, and build developer trust through reliability and clear documentation.
daily_focus: Primary pressure-point: preserve developer trust via Cloud + framework reliability while containing token-migration reputational fallout, without letting the Eliza 2.0 redesign and interoperability ambitions fragment execution.

key_points.topic: Eliza Cloud Reliability & DX: From Early Feature to Trusted Platform
key_points.summary: Cloud surfaced user-facing failures (app creator “operation failed”) alongside signs of maturation (billing top-ups, ongoing cleanups), while core DX improved via backend hot reload and clearer model-provider parameter formats—yet support/documentation gaps persist.

deliberation_items.text: What reliability threshold must Eliza Cloud meet before we publicly position it as “launch-ready” rather than “early access”?
context: ElizaBAO: “operation failed” with elizacloud app creator; cjft: “it’s working but it’s an early feature” (Discord 2026-01-09, #💬-coders)

answer_1.text: Gate on SLOs: define and hit baseline uptime/error-budget targets + reproducible onboarding success before any launch messaging.
answer_1.implication: Strengthens “Execution Excellence” credibility but slows growth/marketing beats.

answer_2.text: Soft-launch now: keep “early access” framing, ship weekly fixes, and recruit power users to harden reliability in production.
answer_2.implication: Accelerates feedback loops but risks compounding public trust damage if failures remain visible.

answer_3.text: Split the surface: publicly launch only the stable path (deploy/run/billing) while keeping app creator behind an explicit beta flag.
answer_3.implication: Preserves momentum while isolating fragile components and reducing support load.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How should we prioritize “last-mile” fixes: product UX polish vs. operational debugging vs. documentation closure?
context: New UI/UX issues created: agent status visibility, signup prompt clickability, redirect back to previous chat (Daily dev summary 2026-01-09)
Unanswered user questions: Discord timer/interval settings; Twitter API requirements (Discord 2026-01-09)

answer_1.text: Ops-first: treat any “operation failed” / deployment blockers as P0 until resolved; postpone UX polish.
answer_1.implication: Maximizes platform reliability but may keep onboarding friction high for new builders.

answer_2.text: Docs-first: close the highest-frequency unanswered questions and broken docs surfaces to reduce support churn.
answer_2.implication: Improves builder self-serve and trust, but may not address underlying runtime defects fast enough.

answer_3.text: Balanced sprint: enforce a fixed capacity split (e.g., 50% ops, 30% UX, 20% docs) with weekly review.
answer_3.implication: Reduces whiplash and preserves momentum across priorities, at the cost of slower single-thread breakthroughs.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: Do we standardize and prominently document the “provider/model” naming convention as part of Cloud’s contract of reliability?
context: cjft: model must use provider prefixes like “openai/gpt-4o-mini”, “anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5”, “google/gemini-2.5-flash” to avoid “Model not found” (Discord 2026-01-07)

answer_1.text: Yes—treat it as a stable public API contract with validation + friendly error messages + docs front-and-center.
answer_1.implication: Reduces integration failures and support load; increases perceived platform maturity.

answer_2.text: Hide it—auto-infer providers from model names and maintain an internal mapping layer for compatibility.
answer_2.implication: Improves UX but increases backend complexity and potential ambiguity in model routing.

answer_3.text: Hybrid—keep explicit prefixes but add a guided UI selector and CLI linting to prevent misconfiguration.
answer_3.implication: Preserves clarity while reducing developer footguns, aligning with “Developer First.”

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.topic: Eliza 2.0: Architectural Reset vs. Execution Excellence
key_points.summary: A major redesign is in motion: a Claude-friendly runtime with consistent abstractions across TypeScript/Rust/Python and FFI plugin interop, explicitly removing API/server/CLI/projects—high upside for composability and long-term scalability, but high risk of fragmenting near-term stability work.

deliberation_items.text: Should the Council bless Eliza 2.0 as the primary trajectory now, or enforce a staged approach that protects v1.x reliability commitments?
context: shaw: “Eliza 2.0… eliminates the current API, server, CLI, and projects… TS, Rust, Python… FFI plugin interoperability… already have a working port on a branch” (Discord 2026-01-09, #core-devs)
v1.7.0 issues: bootstrap/Discord compatibility and serverId→messageServerId migration fallout (Discord 2026-01-07)

answer_1.text: Full pivot: prioritize Eliza 2.0 and freeze major v1.x work except critical fixes.
answer_1.implication: Maximizes long-term platform coherence but risks near-term trust erosion if v1 users feel abandoned.

answer_2.text: Parallel tracks: dedicate a strike team to v1 stability/Cloud while a separate team advances 2.0 behind a strict compatibility plan.
answer_2.implication: Reduces risk but requires disciplined staffing and clear governance to avoid duplicated effort.

answer_3.text: Stage gate 2.0: require a formal RFC, migration plan, and “minimum parity” checklist before allocating substantial capacity.
answer_3.implication: Prevents strategic thrash and aligns with execution excellence, but slows experimentation velocity.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: What is the non-negotiable “developer-first” deliverable for Eliza 2.0: runtime docs, plugin parity, or interop across languages?
context: shaw: “Claude-friendly documented runtime… same abstractions across three languages with examples for common use cases” (Discord 2026-01-09)
Current ecosystem pressure: Discord plugin release blockers and compatibility issues (weekly summary Jan 4–10, 2026; Discord 2026-01-07)

answer_1.text: Docs and examples first: ship the Claude-friendly runtime documentation as the flagship artifact, even with limited plugin parity.
answer_1.implication: Optimizes for adoption and contributor onboarding, but may disappoint teams needing production connectors.

answer_2.text: Plugin parity first: ensure core connectors (Discord, SQL, chain) are stable and portable before expanding language coverage.
answer_2.implication: Protects reliability and reference implementations, but slows the cross-language vision.

answer_3.text: Interop first: deliver FFI plugin boundaries and a working TS↔Rust↔Python plugin demo to prove composability.
answer_3.implication: Establishes a durable ecosystem standard, but risks being too abstract for most developers initially.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How do we prevent a repeat of v1.7.0-style migration breakage as we reshape core abstractions for 2.0?
context: Odilitime: serverId→messageServerId migration caused “No server ID found 10” issues; advised downgrades and fix branches (Discord 2026-01-07)
PR #6333: “fix… serverId => messageServerId change” to restore compatibility (Discord 2026-01-07)

answer_1.text: Strict compatibility policy: versioned schemas, automated migration tests, and “no silent rename” rules.
answer_1.implication: Increases engineering overhead but materially improves reliability and developer confidence.

answer_2.text: Fast iteration policy: accept breaking changes early; communicate aggressively; provide downgrade paths only.
answer_2.implication: Speeds innovation but risks ecosystem fragmentation and churn among integrators.

answer_3.text: Compatibility middleware: add adapters/shims in runtime so old and new plugin contracts can co-exist during transition.
answer_3.implication: Reduces breakage while migrating, but can create long-lived complexity if not sunset aggressively.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.topic: Ecosystem Trust: Token Migration Fallout, Exchange Delistings, and Utility Narrative
key_points.summary: Community trust is under strain from migration eligibility errors, LP “max amount reached” confusion, and confirmed Korean exchange delistings attributed to rebrand/swap transparency; simultaneously, questions about token utility remain unanswered—creating a strategic communications and product-narrative risk.

deliberation_items.text: What is our immediate trust-repair posture for token migration and exchange delisting concerns: operational clarity, public accountability, or incentive alignment?
context: Korean exchanges (Bithumb, Coinone, Korbit) delisting scheduled Feb 2026; DAXA cited “lack of transparency in rebranding/token swap procedures” (Discord 2026-01-08)
Users reporting eligibility issues (0 eligible tokens; LP “max amount reached” errors) (Discord 2026-01-08)

answer_1.text: Operational clarity first: publish a single canonical migration playbook + FAQs + timelines, and staff support until backlog is cleared.
answer_1.implication: Most directly reduces confusion and scams, restoring baseline trust through execution.

answer_2.text: Public accountability: issue a post-mortem on swap/rebrand process and a corrective plan addressing DAXA’s transparency critique.
answer_2.implication: Signals maturity and governance readiness, but may elevate scrutiny and legal/compliance sensitivity.

answer_3.text: Incentive alignment: offer targeted remediation (fee rebates/credits) for impacted cohorts to restore goodwill quickly.
answer_3.implication: Buys goodwill fast but can set precedent and attract opportunistic claims if verification is weak.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How should we answer the strategic critique: “why does the token exist if it isn’t used for payments or gas in the ecosystem”?
context: stoikol: “why the token isn't being used for payments or gas fees… fundamental need for a token without clear utility” (Discord 2026-01-08)

answer_1.text: Utility roadmap commitment: define near-term primitives (Cloud credits, marketplace fees, staking for agent reputation) with dates and owners.
answer_1.implication: Transforms skepticism into an execution checklist, but creates deadlines the org must meet.

answer_2.text: Governance-first framing: position the token primarily for ecosystem coordination (grants, curation, security) rather than payment rails.
answer_2.implication: Clarifies purpose but may disappoint users expecting transactional utility and immediate demand drivers.

answer_3.text: De-emphasize token: focus messaging on open-source framework value; treat token as optional peripheral until product-market fit is proven.
answer_3.implication: Protects developer-first credibility, but reduces leverage of token-led ecosystem growth narratives.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: Do we centralize “truth sources” (contract address, migration status, exchange guidance) into a single council-governed portal to reduce misinformation?
context: Community: contract address hard to find; team to post CA across official X accounts and refresh linktree (Discord 2026-01-07)
Conflicting answers about whether exchanges auto-migrate holdings (Discord 2026-01-08)

answer_1.text: Yes—one canonical portal (status page + FAQ + signed announcements) referenced by all accounts and bots.
answer_1.implication: Reduces confusion/scams and aligns with “Trust Through Shipping,” at the cost of process discipline.

answer_2.text: Partial—keep portal minimal, but empower Discord helpers with templated responses and pinned messages per channel.
answer_2.implication: Faster to deploy but may allow drift across channels and languages over time.

answer_3.text: No—distribute information across platforms (X, Discord, GitHub) and rely on community amplification.
answer_3.implication: Lowest overhead but highest risk of inconsistent guidance and reputational damage.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.
